Patch Set 11: Code-Review+2
Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 1e76060a37b960851faa2ea469ce2472f9741bfe
Adding Willy and Anh who worked on fd recently

Does "2" have a special meaning? Does it warrant having a comment explaining the different codes? or are just just unique placeholder so that we can look back later?

EDIT: it looks like it means ONGOING perhaps from reading `subprojects/dhcp-done/update-dhcp-status.cpp`. Should there be an "error" status?

I can add a comment here. ONGOING or 2 just means (do nothing and just log) for the remote side. https://docs.google.com/document/d/1__fQaB_TayULT7wknmiYp3CWCM4CM0MJDITehuiBS2c/edit?tab=t.0#heading=h.17wg41voij6q
Done, added a comment
Should we use managed_fd from stdplus
yeah I can check that, doesn't know that we have a fd util in stdplus

Looks like it mainly brings some lifecycle management for file descriptor, here we really just do one time read/write and closed it in this funciton, and do not maintain the fd at all. so I think there is no need to switch to that.
If you use the managedfd class you can get rid of many of the if statement conditionals and just handle errors at the point where you are retrieving the status via exception.
ack, will do
Done

Don't add build time options for strings, if we need an override make it possible at runtime via the command line or environment variables.

I think we can hardcode this string just fine for our purposes at this time. We don't want to encourage people to have to build different binaries just to change a path,
ack, will do
Done
It looks like --create isn't explained in print_usage
I do not add it because it is supposed to be an internal usage only by gbmc-br-dhcp. A hook script that wants to add logs should never use -create
Thanks, I'll let William take a final look before we submit

It would be better to just drop this requirement of having a file at all. Just have the specific behavior occur when the daemon gets an `ENOENT` to say there is no update happening.

You probably do want to distinguish "ONGOING" from "NO_UPDATE_IN_PROGRESS" or whatever name. I guess just the descriptive string is good enough, but it might be nice for automation to have different codes for those.

We can do that and move the file creation to gbmc-br-dhcp. We can add another code NO_UPDATE_IN_PROGRESS when no file is there. But remote side might not seen it at all, since it will always trigger dhcp then read the port.
Removed the file check. Also I sent clear logs when file does not exists. Not adding a new code though since I have to check if the other side supports that, we know that it supports 0,1,2 for now.
I mean, can't you just leave it as `ONGOING` for ENOENT but just say there is no error in the process.

I thought about it but looks like there is no need to do that here? the upgrade process always invoke gbmc-br-dhcp first and message reading happens later, so it should be created already.

Even message reading happens before somehow, it still works since the remote will just receive a "no such file or directory" with an ongoing status (handled in dhcp-done.cpp)
If you keep the behavior of read / open errors just turning into `ONGOING` + error message then yes, it should be fine to just pass that through.
Yeah I will keep the read error part. so we don't need this.

I would avoid locks entirely here, they can just cause contention between many readers and the writer of the update.

Just use https://github.com/openbmc/stdplus/blob/master/include-fd/stdplus/fd/atomic.hpp for the writer side and you don't have to worry about any locking on the reader side. It guarantees the file contents get updated atomically by writing to a tempfile and leveraging `rename`.

You also wouldn't need to differentiate updating and creating a new file.

Networkd uses this along with a formatter so that numbers and formatted data can be trivially written out.

https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-networkd/blob/master/src/config_parser.cpp#L284
atomicwriter seems a perfect fit here, our writers are mostly sequential but reader can interleave, will switch to that.
Done

Why even parse the message here? I would just make the file contents exactly what you want to send in the UDP message so the writer of the file is in charge of setting it up correctly and you don't need to have more code re-packing.
It is mostly for readability/debugbility, cating the file can return us a readable status and messages (which is a command I plan to add to the remote debugging cmd).
Why not just do the parsing only in the tool to dump the message? You already want to translate the code into a string.
Done
This is complicated enough (has arguments) that you should just use `getopt`. You can see `nemorad` for an example.
will do
After removing create, it has no argument anymore, usage is just update-dhcp-status.cpp <status> <message>
This works

Really? Wouldn't this always point to a logic error that needs to fail at install time? I mean, I guess you could have a transient read failure but I just don't think it can actually happen.

Also, you can safely collapse this into a single `catch (const std::exception &e)` as all exceptions should derive from that class.
collapsed the error handler
Don't create an uninitialized fd, just declare and define in one line.
Done

I would just drop the ifstream entirely and use `stdplus::LineReader` on the `fd` above.

If you want to parse the code from int (although i really think it would be better just to write the file in packet format and do a `stdplus::fd::readAll()` here), just use `stdplus::fromStr<int>(code_string)` in `stdplus/numeric/str.hpp`
I removed the encoding/decoding, we can just do extra steps when trying to parse the status code from the file for debugging purpose
Just use append and a format string so that you don't need the intermediate string `out.append("{}\n{}", status.code, status.message)`
not needed if no encoding/decoding
You should refactor the meson.build for the `src/meson.build` to build a static library that can be included here and as part of the executable to prevent multiple compilation of `file-io.cpp`
Done
nit: prefer `stdplus::print` or `stdplus::println` over `iostream` variants.
Done
Catch `const std::exception &` so you can print out the `e.what()` with the error.
Done
Thanks for the review!
